title-group.article-title: Productivity Effects on the Wage Premium of Mexican Maquiladoras

article-meta.aff: 1University of Texas-Pan American, Edinburg, TX, USA
2Tecnológico de Monterrey, Campus Monterrey, Monterrey, Mexico

author-notes.corresp: André Varella Mollick, Department of Economics and Finance, University of Texas-Pan American, 1201 West University Dr., Edinburg, TX 78539-2999, USA. Email: amollick@utpa.edu

abstract.p: The wage premium between skilled and unskilled workers in Mexican maquiladoras has increased, from nearly 2 times in 1981 to nearly 4 or 5 times in 2006, depending on the sector. This increase favoring skilled workers is examined against relative labor supplies within a class of models estimated by dynamic panel methods. Adapting a conventional model of the skill premium to labor supply, we find strong productivity effects. Higher productivity at the maquiladora industry (assumed either exogenous or endogenous to the wage premium) or higher U.S. GDP per worker (exogenous to the industry) are shown to have positive effects on the wage premium. The elasticity of wages to relative labor supply is very stable, implying strong substitution of labor types. We find, however, evidence of structural breaks in the basic model around the start of the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994 and 1995.

body.p: What determines the rising ratios between wages of skilled and unskilled workers over time? A very well-known model of the skill premium by Katz and Murphy (1992) conveys the idea that technological developments occur at a constant rate, but the supply of skilled workers grows at different rates. When the relative supply of skilled workers (relative to unskilled) grows faster than technology, the skill premium (relative wages between skilled and unskilled workers) falls. When the relative labor supply falls short of this rate the skill premium increases. Katz and Murphy (1992) estimate a value of −0.709 for the response of relative wages to relative labor supply, which implies that the elasticity of substitution is around 1.41 for the U.S. labor market, using annual data from 1963 to 1987. They also report a 0.033 trend coefficient, which can be interpreted as a positive effect of technology on wages or, more generally, of skill-biased technical change (SBTC), as in Berman, Bound, and Griliches (1994).

This article reconsiders this basic model of relative wages in the context of the Mexican maquiladora industry for at least four reasons. First, the maquiladoras are examples of global production-sharing firms discussed by Hummels, Ishii, and Yi (2001) and Helg and Tajoli (2005), among others. Viewed in this way, the industry has been buttressed by substantial advances in the adoption of new technologies, although Mexico itself benefited enormously from capital inflows after the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), as documented by Feenstra and Hanson (1997) for the maquiladoras and, more recently, Waldkirch, Nunnenkamp, and Bremont (2009) for the manufacturing sector. Second, the quality of the data for the Mexican maquiladoras provided by the National Institute of Statistics is very good, which allows us to perform a simple decomposition of time in the original Katz and Murphy (1992) model into factors of interest, such as productivity. Third, the maquiladoras have become the engine of growth in Mexico. The importance of the industry to the Mexican economy is not only remarkable but also growing.1 Furthermore, the study of factors explaining the evolution of wage premium or wage inequality due to skill is important from a policy perspective. In a developing country like Mexico, if for example trade is the key driver, policy may be aimed to adopt protectionist trade policies in order to reduce inequality. In contrast, society may be more likely to tolerate an increase in wage inequality if this change is largely driven by advances in technology. An increasing trend of the ratio of wages of skilled to unskilled labor calls for policy directed to promote education and training of lower-skilled workers. In addition, if it is possible to look at the determinants of wage premium by economic sector, then industrial policy could be focused by sector. This combination of factors makes it important to study the major changes that are driving this important industry.

Previous research for Mexico has focused on trade liberalization episodes, which for Mexico are either the mid-1980s after joining the GATT or 1994 with NAFTA channeling higher bilateral trade with Canada and the United States. These trade liberalization approaches captured the country’s opening to foreign trade and slashing of tariffs and quotas. Cragg and Epelbaum (1996) show that between 1987 and 1993 the wages of urban workers with a primary education (Grade 6 completed) fell relative to the wages of urban workers with secondary education (completed Grade 9) by 15% and relative to the wages of urban workers with postsecondary education by 60%. Hanson and Harrison (1999) discuss the period from 1984 to 1990 in Mexico. Montes Rojas (2006) estimates demand and supply factors that affect the Mexican skill premium. For technology effects on the skill premium, see Esquivel and Rodríguez-López (2003), who find that trade liberalization would have led to a reduction in the wage gap in Mexico from 1988 to 1994, but that this was offset by the large negative impact of technological progress on the real wage of unskilled workers. Hanson (2003) reports that in Mexico during the 1990s, the returns to skill continued to rise and regional differences in wages continued to widen, with the largest wage gains in regions being those most exposed to international trade, foreign direct investment, and/or opportunities for migration to the United States. Robertson (2004) examines changes in relative output prices from the mid-1980s to the late 1990s. Goldberg and Pavcnik (2007), Chusseau, Dumont, and Hellier (2008), and Crinò (2009) contain recent surveys of the evidence surrounding this research agenda.

The behavior of the maquiladoras’ skill premium (defined as the relative wage between administrative workers and manual workers) amid trade openness, economic crisis, and stabilization has been discussed before by Mollick (2008a), who examined the skill premium under a time series perspective for the aggregate of the maquiladora industry. This article revisits this issue under detailed disaggregated data that sheds light on the behavior of several important characteristics across 12 different sectors: food, textiles, shoes and leather, furniture, chemicals, transportation equipment, machinery (other than electronic), electronic machinery, materials and electronics, toys and sports goods, others, and services. With different sectors, the skill premium responds differently to labor supplies and to any other factors linked to the SBTC hypothesis. In the panel data context, however, we are interested in a single measure of the effect of the independent variables on the wage premium in which the time series and cross-section dimensions are used jointly. To handle endogenous labor supplies (that may respond to wage premiums), the data for 12 sectors across 1981 to 2006 are estimated by dynamic panel regressions.

Several features of the data suggest a reexamination of the Katz and Murphy (1992) model. The average wage premium ratio of 3.234 in the pre-NAFTA years (1981-1993) rises to 4.413 in the post-NAFTA years (1994-2006), a 36.5% rate of increase between the (averages of) two subsamples. There are also more substantial variations across sectors as documented below. The relative supply of skilled workers rose about 9.6% between the two subsamples. Labor productivity also faced a slower growth in the pre-NAFTA years and a much more aggressive growth in the post-NAFTA years: The index of labor productivity was at 89.5 in the pre-NAFTA years, rising to 757.3 in the post-NAFTA years—a 668% growth rate between the two subperiods!

To answer how relative wages in a predominantly export-oriented sector respond to factors affecting either the degree of capital intensity or productivity, our research strategy compares the basic Katz and Murphy (1992) model in light of important recent advances on technological change, capital–skill complementarity, and business cycle effects. Adapting the conventional model by Katz and Murphy (1992) of the skill premium to labor supply, we find strong productivity effects. Higher productivity at the maquiladora industry (assumed either exogenous or endogenous to the wage premium) or higher U.S. GDP per worker (exogenous to the industry) are shown to have positive effects on the wage premium. The elasticity of wages to relative labor supply is very stable, implying strong substitution of labor types. Our empirical estimates for Mexican maquiladoras confirm the positive output effects on wages, but do not find effects caused by the intensity of imported inputs, contrary to what Dinopoulos, Syropoulos, Xu, and Yotov (2011) reported for sectors of Mexican manufacturing. While taking the positive output effects as showing substantial linkages with productivity (and also with the U.S. economy), we provide other interpretations of our findings.

sec.title: Data Description
sec.p: Annual data available for the 1981 to 2006 period are used. This is the longest period possible with detailed information on relative labor types and maquiladora expenditures. The period includes, around its midpoint, NAFTA coming into effect in 1994. All data are from Mexico’s Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía (INEGI) in the “Banco de Información Económica” section (http://www.inegi.gob.mx), with a focus on the subsections on “industria maquiladora de exportación.” In contrast with Mexican manufacturing data, the maquiladora data are based on national coverage through surveys of all firms that were awarded the authorization to operate as a “maquiladora firm.”

As measures of industry employment, the number of production workers (L, unskilled) and nonproduction workers (H, skilled) are considered. This two-tier classification has been adopted by many studies, such as Berman et al. (1994). For the Mexican case, Robertson (2004) looks at additional data sources and shows that production workers have less education in every industry than nonproduction workers and concludes that the two-tier distinction to classify skill intensity is valid in Mexico. For the skilled labor premium, we take: Ws from “empleados administrativos,” management employees or skilled workers, Wu from “obreros” or unskilled workers; both in pesos. Mexico’s INEGI provides data on hours worked for unskilled workers and for total workers, which comprises all three types of workers in the sector maquiladoras: management personnel, technicians, and laborers. We use hours worked for all types of workers.

In Figure 1, the skill premium in the maquiladoras (wswu) moves up in general across the 12 sectors varying from 2 in 1981 to 4 or more in 2006. This means that a skilled worker in the sector in 2006 earns on average 4 times higher than an unskilled worker does, up from 2 times that of an unskilled worker in 1981.2 Except for chemicals, in which the skill premium had no data for 2 years, the skill premium is usually growing over time. Second, the relative participation of nonproduction workers in the total maquiladora workforce (hl) has also fluctuated, but not by much, except for the abnormal spike in chemicals (Sector 5). Being consistently below the 12% or 13% level, Figure 2 confirms the general notion that the maquiladora industry is very intensive in unskilled workers. Sectors 10 (toys) and 12 (services) had the highest rise in the skilled labor share (H/L) over time, from 2% to 10% and from 6% to 11%, respectively. Due to the data problems mentioned above, the chemical sector will be excluded from the empirical work below.

sec.p: Third, we can think of output effects (from either U.S. economic activity or own maquiladora value added) on the wage premium. Although the measure of productivity in each sector can be ascertained by the ratio of value-added to hours worked, a natural destination of Mexican maquiladora exports is the extent of the U.S. market, which makes the level of economic activity in the destination country particularly interesting.3 The labor productivity ratios reproduced in Figure 3 show a clear rising trend with a visible change in the slope around the middle of the sample in the 1990s. It appears that productivity rose slowly in the beginning of the sample (1980s) and increased at a faster rate later on. This is not consistent with the standard Katz and Murphy (1992) model, which assumes a linear time trend. Figure 4 contains U.S. GDP and value added in U.S. manufacturing (in US$ billion), together with U.S. GDP per worker and value added per employer in U.S. manufacturing, from 1981 to 2006. The upper chart shows the rising trends in both measures and the lower chart displays the rising average productivity in the United States, defined either in terms of total real U.S. GDP or U.S. value added in the manufacturing sector only. The U.S. GDP and manufacturing value added are from the Bureau of Economic Analysis (http://www.bea.gov/national/index.htm#gdp), and the number of employees from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (http://www.bls.gov/ces/). Houseman, Kurz, Lengermann, and Mandel (2011) contain detailed evidence of “offshoring bias” in U.S. manufacturing.

sec.p: Some of the data properties (reported in Table 1) have been mentioned in the Introduction, such as the increases in the ratios of wage premiums, relative labor supplies, and labor productivity. In addition, the correlation coefficients (not reported in Table 1) between relative wages and labor supply are low at 0.108 for the entire sample (0.018 for the pre-1994 years and 0.441 for the post-1994 years). Relative wages correlate strongly with labor productivity at the sector level: 0.533 for the entire sample (0.403 for the pre-1994 years and 0.193 for the post-1994 years). This fact reinforces the theoretical proposition that wages should pay the marginal product of labor. All other correlation coefficients are very small, with the exception of cor(H/L, VA/hours) = 0.551 for the post-1994 sample: It was 0.146 for the entire sample and only 0.038 for the pre-1994. Thus, only after the mid-1990s there appears to be (positive) co-movements between relative labor supplies and productivity (Table 1).

sec.title: The Model
sec.p: Suppose maquiladoras hire only two types of workers—skilled (H) and unskilled (L)—who are imperfect substitutes and supply labor inelastically. Suppose workers are risk-neutral, maximize the present value of labor income, and labor markets are competitive. Under a separable constant elasticity of substitution (CES) production function, as in Acemoglu (2002):

where ρ ≤ 1 and ALt and AHt are factor-augmenting technology terms. The elasticity of substitution between the two types of workers is σ ≡ 1/(1 − ρ). The two types of workers are gross substitutes when σ > 1 (or ρ > 0) and gross complements when σ < 1 (or ρ < 0). Special cases include Leontieff fixed proportions (σ → 0 or ρ → −∞), perfect substitution (σ → ∞), and the CES function collapsing to the Cobb-Douglas case (σ → 1).

Under competitive labor markets, one can calculate the unskilled wage as (we omit the t subscript): WL = ∂Y/∂L = ALρ[ALρ + AHρ(H/L)ρ](1 − ρ)/ρ. Similarly, the optimal skilled wage is given by WH = ∂Y/∂H = AHρ[ALρ(H/L)−ρ + AHρ](1 − ρ)/ρ. Combining these first-order conditions, the skill premium becomes
or, in logarithmic form,

The skill premium increases with the scarcity of skilled workers: the partial derivative is −(1/σ) < 0. The substitution effect shows that, for given skill bias of technology (the term AH/AL), the relative demand curve is downward sloping with elasticity 1/σ = (1 − ρ). The skill premium responds to technology, depending on the elasticity of substitution [(σ − 1)/σ]. If σ > 1, improvements in the skill-complementary technology increase w. This would be a shift out of the relative demand curve.

Note that as H/L increases, w should fall, which would graphically represent a rightward shift in the relative vertical labor supply. But this tendency of falling w could be compensated by changes in technology in the first term of the RHS of (3). Recent past U.S. experience is consistent with the demand for skills having increased to prevent the relative wages of skilled workers from declining.
As suggested by Acemoglu (2002), the hypothesis that technical change has taken place steadily that can be captured by
where trend is calendar time. Substituting (4) into (3) immediately yields:
or

which is the testable equation in many studies, such as Manacorda, Sánchez-Paramo, and Schady (2010), carrying the idea that technological developments occur at a constant rate, but the supply of skilled workers grows at different rates. When H/L grows faster than the rate of SBTC, w will fall. When H/L falls short of this rate, w will increase. Estimating a value of −0.709 for β2 in (6) with R2 = 0.52, Katz and Murphy (1992) argue that σ = 1.41 for the U.S. labor market using annual data for 1963 to 1987.

The elasticity of the substitution parameter is admittedly difficult to estimate, since it combines substitution between and within industries.4 Krusell, Ohanian, Ríos-Rull, and Volante (2000) hypothesize that capital–skill complementarity may be important for understanding wage inequality because the stock of equipment has been growing at a very high rate in recent years. Acemoglu (2002) introduces this idea to U.S. data and conjectures that if the decline in the relative price of equipment capital is related to the increase in the demand for skills, it should proxy in (5) for the demand for skills and performs better than a linear trend.5

The time trend is linear and deterministic, which means it could have a very stable component, as captured by (4) above. However, the time trend cannot admittedly capture all that it should, since any measure of productivity varies with the degree on which new technologies are being absorbed by skilled workers. Caselli (1999), for example, distinguishes between revolutionary technological change that modifies the wage structure and incremental technologies that do not. His working hypothesis is that technological progress was primarily incremental in the 1950s and 1960s and primarily revolutionary (of the skill-biased variety) in the 1970s and 1980s, with the information technology revolution.

We adopt a similar motivation in this article, in which the driving forces will be productivity changes combined with the level of intra-industry trade. Given the data set of the Mexican maquiladora industry, which contains enough information to generate measures of productivity and of imported inputs usage, we introduce these “observables” into the modified equations as follows:

where VA/hours is our measure of productivity in Mexican maquiladoras: It reflects how much is produced per money spent on labor hours at the industry; USGDP/L is a similar measure for the main destination of goods and services of the industry—U.S. GDP divided by workers, thus capturing average productivity in the U.S. economy6—and imp/inputs is the share of imported inputs with respect to total inputs to capture intra-industry trade. Kleinert (2003), for example, captures the extent of intermediate goods in total imports and the imported inputs of a sector from another sector, and Dinopoulos et al. (2011) use the index of intra-industry trade. Although some articles in the literature on country-level studies adopt the openness definition with imports divided by the sum of imports and exports, we have for the maquiladora industry total inputs used in the industry from either domestic or from foreign sectors. Almost all production in the maquiladora sector is sold abroad. In order not to make any unnecessary assumptions, it is natural to gauge the import content of this industry using the definition above: share of imported inputs with respect to total inputs used in production. We will refer to this figure as the intensity of imported inputs.

Hanson, Mataloni, and Slaughter (2005) and Chongvilaivan, Hur, and Riyanto (2009) have focused on the construction of “outsourcing” measures in recent studies, and Ng (2010) discusses the fragmentation of production across countries. Dinopoulos et al. (2011), in particular, build a theoretical model in which they suppose the efficiency of high-skilled and low-skilled labor is increasing in firm-specific output. Allowing for a Chamberlinian mechanism in a monopolistic competitive sector, intra-industry trade in their model can increase firm size and raise industry-wide productivity. In addition, the output elasticity of substitution is captured by the percentage change in the relative demand for high-skilled labor brought about by a small percentage change in firm output. If this elasticity is positive, an increase in output raises the relative demand for high-skilled labor, thus raising the skill premium. In (7) the time trend is removed under the assumption that productivity (and imp/inputs share more generally, although not in our data for the maquiladora having remarkably high import/inputs shares) captures the trend-like effect.

As mentioned earlier, Figure 1 is consistent with a rising wage premium overall for the maquiladoras over the 1981 to 2006 years. It is important to note, however, that the different samples may provide different patterns as far as these ratios are concerned. Mollick (2008b), for example, examines two samples of Mexican manufacturing (with maquiladoras excluded) and documents rising wage premiums (defined similarly than in this article) in the 1987 to 1995 sample and slightly declining wage premiums in the 1994 to 2007 sample.

We expect β2 to be between 0 and 1 (the closer to 1 the higher the persistence); β3 to be negative as discussed in the theoretical model above; β4 to be positive (under business cycle effects benefiting skilled workers relatively more) following Lindquist (2004), Beaudry and Green (2005), and Dinopoulos et al. (2011); and β5 to be negative if the Chamberlinian mechanism in Dinopoulos et al. (2011) is operative.

Employing the class of estimators developed by Arellano and Bond (1991), we perform the estimates below assuming endogeneity of relative labor supply as (RHS) regressors. We therefore allow for relative labor supply responding to changes in the wage premium, which is the dependent variable in the models above. All the other regressors (than labor supplies) are assumed exogenous, which can be explained as follows. Productivity is certainly related to wages in theory, but being entirely determined by the U.S. economy (in the case of average labor productivity of the U.S. economy) it is not difficult to justify that wage changes in the maquiladora do not have an impact on this productivity variable. The same reasoning goes for the ratio between imported and total inputs being entirely exogenous to relative wages. Yet we do allow for the possibility that wage changes have an impact on productivity of the maquiladora industry (measured by value added divided by hours). Linearity is assumed for convenience, following Acemoglu (2002), and we explore longer lag dynamics for robustness purposes.

sec.p: The elasticity of substitution between the two labor types is derived by computing (−1/σ) = β2 on ln(H/L) in (6) or (7). In Table 2, when the 11 sectors (excluding chemicals) are considered in column 1, we obtain a −0.090 value of the β3 coefficient, which implies a high value of σ of 11.11, the elasticity of substitution in the two labor types. The estimate suggests that the wage premium moves in tandem with the relative supply of skilled workers: As relative supply of skilled workers rises, their relative wage falls as predicted from the theory. This magnitude implies a very high substitution of labor types since recent empirical estimates in Manacorda et al. (2010) suggest σ range between 2.6 and 5.2 in Latin American countries. The value of σ > 2 suggests that the rise in H/L encourages so much SBTC that the demand for skills increases more than enough to offset the potential increase in the supply of skills, as derived in Acemoglu (2002). The specification tests in Table 2 are mixed. The AB (2) is never rejected at standard significance levels but the Sargan test does not confirm the good specification, casting doubt on the validity of instruments. The AB (2) tests based on a second-order serial correlation test of the residuals from the difference equation indicate that the use of endogenous t − 3 dated variables is valid since there is no serial correlation of Order 2. The Sargan test of overidentifying restrictions (for testing orthogonality between the instruments and the residuals) does reject the null hypothesis in almost all columns. We conjecture that one problem might be that wage premium can have an impact on relative labor supply: As the wage premium rises, we should expect an increase in the supply of skilled relative to unskilled workers.

Support for SBTC is obtained in the estimation of the time trend in column 1 (KM stands for the Katz and Murphy (1992) model), which is statistically significant and positive. The value of β1 is around 0.011, in agreement with the expected positive value if technical change is skill biased. Katz and Murphy (1992) report an overall value for the U.S. labor market over 1963 to 1987 of a 0.033 trend coefficient for annual data. The parameter associated with the lagged wage premium (β2) is around half, suggesting mild persistence.

Column 2 of Table 2 indicates that U.S. productivity (assumed exogenous) has a positive effect on the skill premium (0.285). However, the U.S. GDP per worker series does not vary across sectors and the coefficient is thus likely to be capturing time effects for the overall of the maquiladora industry. The output coefficient when maquiladora value added is used in column 4 goes down remarkably to 0.064, but it is still statistically significant at the 5% level. Column 5 modifies the treatment of maquiladora value added: It is now assumed to be endogenous to the wage premium. This changes the implied elasticity of substitution to around 14 but does not change the coefficient of maquiladora productivity, which decreases from 0.064 in column 4 to 0.051 in column 5. Higher labor productivity at the maquiladora thus has a positive output effect on the skill premium.

Across columns 2 to 5 in Table 2, the values for the β3 coefficients do not change much across specifications, implying a high value of σ of between 10.64 and 10.99 in columns 1 to 3. The share of imports per total inputs is negative, but not statistically significant in columns 3 and 4. The β6 coefficient on imported share of inputs is much higher in absolute value (when value added is assumed endogenous to wage premium), but not statistically significant as before. Interestingly, the Sargan test suggests valid instruments in column 5 when maquiladora value added (adjusted for hours) is assumed to be endogenous to the skill premium.

These results are very much preserved in Table 3 under H/L endogenous. The degree of persistence increases only slightly to more than 0.50 for the β2 coefficient in columns 1 to 3. The major change lies in the value of the labor supply elasticity: The β3 coefficient now is reduced to around −0.04 when statistically significant in columns 1 to 2, which imply considerably higher σs. All the specification tests are now very good, including the Sargan tests of validity of instruments. Note that output effects on the skill premium are again positive under exogenous U.S. output (varying from 0.229 to 0.232) and under maquiladora VA (varying from 0.047 to 0.054), no matter the specific treatment of Mexican output (exogenous in column 4 and endogenous in column 5) with respect to the wage premium. This suggests that output has positive effects on the wage premium.

To perform the effect of NAFTA and the structural change on the model parameters, we initially ran all of the models with data from 1981 to 1993 and from 1994 to 2006. Table 4 employs a longer dynamic panel model with two (or three) autoregressive terms, depending on the subsample, as needed to attain as much satisfactory as possible AB (2) statistics. As the results show, there is considerable variation in the fit of the models across the subsamples: The model tends to be appropriate for the pre-NAFTA years when the elasticity of substitution is always statistically significant and varies between 4 and 5 (4.65 in the original KM model). Yet the models fail miserably for the second subsample, since relative labor supply is never statistically significant. As before, output has positive effects on the wage premium in the first subsample: It is much higher when U.S. output per worker is used (0.496) than when maquiladora output per worker is used; 0.070 when output is assumed exogenous and 0.058 when output is assumed endogenous.

In the first subsample, the instruments are valid only in column 4 when maquiladora VA is assumed endogenous to the skill premium. In the second subsample, the instruments appear to be valid, but there is still serial correlation in the residuals despite the longer lags (3) used. More important, neither relative labor supply nor any of the output measures are statistically significant in the second subsample.

Table 5 breaks the sample 1 year later than in Table 4: from 1981 to 1994 and from 1995 to 2006. Now the elasticity of labor substitution is sometimes not statistically significant in the first subsample but output effects are always positive: As before, U.S. output per worker or industry value added is positive as in Table 4 only for the first subsample and there is never any impact through intra-industry trade. The basic model of wage premium thus does not find support in the second subsample.

Dinopoulos et al. (2011) estimate similar equations for Mexican manufacturing over 1993 to 2003 and obtain a significant negative relationship between skill intensity and the skill premium (−0.254 with a standard deviation of 0.008) without finding anything on the intra-industry trade. When they control for output, however, they find under instrumental variables (skill intensity and output) that the relationship between skill intensity and the skill premium goes up to −0.279 (with a standard deviation of 0.039), with the output coefficient at 0.273 and intra-industry trade coefficient at −0.130, both now statistically significant. Thus, for Mexican manufacturing intra-industry trade decreases the skill premium and output increases the skill premium in Dinopoulos et al. (2011).8 In our case, although we do confirm the positive output effects in all tables, the output effects are stronger in the first subsample. Moreover, the intensity of imported inputs is never statistically significant, and our most likely explanation is that in the maquiladora sector the import to input share has always been very high throughout: In the first subsample the mean is 91.4% and in the second subsample the mean is 92.6%, which indicate the traditionally high value of the intensity of imported inputs in the Mexican maquiladora with the U.S. economy.

sec.title: Final Remarks
sec.p: Recent work in Beaudry and Green (2005) suggests that the Katz and Murphy (1992) model offers a poor explanation of the recent change in the U.S. college premium: They report odd positive responses of relative wages for relative labor supply for the 1976 to 2000 period. Other modifications of the Katz and Murphy (1992) model include Ciccone and Peri (2005), who define demographics in the choice of instruments for the United States along four decades. For Mexico, Mollick (2008a) explored time series effects of SBTC at maquiladoras, and Waldkirch et al. (2009) quantified employment effects of FDI in manufacturing panels.

Kose, Meredith, and Towe (2005) have identified many changes in the Mexican economy since NAFTA. This research does not attempt to explain the political components associated with the NAFTA trade agreement, which admittedly may have estimated productivity. These effects are difficult to capture in the types of econometric models discussed herein, but more research investigating the channels of rising wages and productivity are certainly welcome. Important for this article is the level of economic integration between Mexico and the United States. Recent studies have also suggested that U.S. multinational corporations have been hiring abroad while cutting back at home: “The companies cut their workforce in the U.S. by 2.9 million during the 2000s while increasing employment overseas by 2.4 million, new data from the U.S. Commerce Department show” (The WSJ, Big U.S. firms shift hiring abroad, April 19, 2011). Houseman et al. (2011) find substantial evidence of off-shoring bias in U.S. manufacturing, which should have an impact on a Mexican industry very much integrated with U.S. production such as the maquiladora.

The driving force of this empirical work is that, as examples of global production-sharing firms, maquiladora firms are likely to respond quickly to technological breakthroughs as captured by labor productivity measures. For Mexican manufacturing over the years 1993 to 2003, Dinopoulos et al. (2011) have documented that intra-industry trade decreases the skill premium and output increases the skill premium in estimations similar to the ones adopted in this article. For the maquiladora sector, we provide evidence of strong output effects (higher productivity leads to higher skill premium), but no effects caused by the intensity of imported inputs. The maquiladora industry has traditionally displayed a large share of imports to total inputs used in production, which suggests that the channel to explain the rising wage premium is not likely to come from the usage of imports in production. On the other hand, we find in all cases strong output effects on the skill premium. This means, in particular, that productivity changes at the U.S. side has an effect favoring the wage premium across the border. As reviewed before, part of much of the evidence on developing countries may be because “there are few developing countries that have received as large FDI flows as Mexico or that have outsourced as big a share of their production as Hong Kong” (Goldberg & Pavcnik, 2007, p. 62). In this article, higher productivity—either by better efficiency in production at the sector level or by strong links with the whole of the U.S. economy—leads to a higher wage premium in Mexican maquiladoras for the 25-year period examined.

According to Mollick (2008a), from 1980 to 2006 the share of maquiladora exports to total Mexican exports has risen by between four and five times; similar figures for imports lie between three and four times the levels of 1980.

The wage premium is a relative price that has been extensively studied in the literature. Labor demand typically estimates functions of skilled labor and unskilled labor separately. In our case, the outcome of these estimates (e.g., wages in wage equations) is put together in a single figure. Therefore, an increase in the wage premium means that the wage of the skilled has grown relative to that of the unskilled. The detailed numbers of the skill premium are as follows: from 2 times in 1981 to 4.3 times in 2006 in Sector 1, from 2.4 in 1981 to 3.5 in 2006 in Sector 2, from 2.2 in 1981 to 3.3 in 2006 in Sector 3, from 2.4 in 1981 to 4 in 2006 in Sector 4, from 1.6 in 1981 to 4.3 in 2006 in Sector 5, from 3 in 1981 to 5.5 in 2006 in Sector 6, from 2.5 in 1981 to 3.9 in 2006 in Sector 7, from 2.5 in 1981 to 4.8 in 2006 in Sector 8, from 2 in 1981 to 5.1 in 2006 in Sector 9, from 4.1 in 1981 to 6.4 in 2006 in Sector 10, from 2 in 1981 to 5.2 in 2006 in Sector 11, and from 1.9 in 1981 to 3.9 in 2006 in Sector 12.

Evidence for Mexican manufacturing in Mollick and Cabral (2009) documents that labor productivity and total-factor productivity diverge; however, one does not have capital stock for the maquiladora sector, and the best one can do is to employ some measure of average productivity as we do in this article.

A convenient assumption is that the industry-level labor supply is perfectly inelastic, implying that—given exogenous quantities—wages are endogenously determined. Although this assumption has its major support on the level of data aggregation used for the whole of the maquiladora industry in other studies, we relax this in the empirical methodology below.

Adding the log of the relative price of capital to (5), Acemoglu (2002) does not find statistically significant capital terms when the time trend is included. When the time trend is excluded, however, the fit of the regression (measured by the adjusted R2) is worse than (5). Acemoglu (2002) concludes that
while this evidence may simply reflect the fact that the relative price of equipment is measured with error, it casts some doubt on the view that the relative price of equipment capital is directly linked to the demand for skills. (p. 29)

U.S. real GDP per worker is a measure of the aggregate of U.S. economic activity. As an alternative measure, we also constructed valued added by the whole manufacturing sector of the United States divided by number of workers in manufacturing. The results were very similar and we are reporting below only those with U.S. GDP/L.

We conducted an extensive search on the specification for the dynamic models. Following the literature on dynamic panels, we look for acceptable values of the Sargan test and also of the AB (2) test, which tests for second-order serial correlation under heteroskedasticity robust specifications. Our basic criteria are that both Sargan and AB (2) tests are satisfied. Rejection of AB (1) is not a major issue since errors can be first-order correlated.

The figures above from Dinopoulos et al. (2011) are for their estimations of skill premia resembling our specifications (7) for the manufacturing sector (not the maquiladora) of Mexico over 1993 to 2003. They use panel fixed effects modeling with instrumental variables in some cases.

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: André Varella Mollick is Professor at the Department of Economics and Finance of the University of Texas-Pan American. He holds a Ph.D. degree in Economics from the University of Tsukuba in Japan. His research areas are: development economics, international finance, and macroeconomics.

Jorge Ibarra-Salazar is an Associate Professor at the Economics Department of the Tecnológico de Monterrey. He holds a Ph.D. degree in Economics from the Southern Methodist University. His research areas are: Mexican fiscal federalism, border economics and decisions under risk.
